ORDER OF PROCEDURE - Mr. Lewis (CA) asked unanimous consent that, during further consideration of H.R. 4939 in the Committee of the Whole pursuant to House Resolution 725, an amendment by Mr. Gilchrest regarding section 3011 and an amendment by Mr. Sabo regarding the Defense Production Act may be offered at any point in the reading, shall be considered as read, shall not be subject to amendment except that the chairman and ranking minority member of the Committee on Appropriations each may offer one pro forma amendment for the purpose of debate and shall not be subject to a demand for the division of the question in the House or in the Committee of the Whole. Each amendment shall be debatable for 20 minutes, equally divided and controlled by the proponent and an opponent.

summary.text:
Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act for Defense, the Global War on Terror, and Hurricane Recovery, 2006 - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2006 for the global war on terror to the Department of Agriculture (DOA) in connection with Foreign Agricultural Service grants.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Defense (DOD) for: (1) military personnel; (2) operation and maintenance (O&M); (3) the Afghanistan Security Forces Fund; (4) the Iraq Security Forces Fund; (5) procurement; (6) research, development, test, and evaluation; (7) Defense Working Capital Funds; (8) the Defense Health Program; (9) drug interdiction and counter-drug activities related to Afghanistan and Central Asia; (10) the Office of the Inspector General; and (11) the Intelligence Community Management Account.

Allows DOD funds to be used for support for counter-drug activities of the Governments of Afghanistan and Pakistan.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for: (1) the United States Agency for International Development (USAID); (2) the Economic Support Fund; (3) the Democracy Fund; (4) international narcotics control and law enforcement; (5) migration and refugee assistance; (6) international affairs technical assistance; and (7) peacekeeping operations.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for: (1) the U.S. Coast Guard; (2) military construction; (3) salaries and expenses of U.S. attorneys, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives; (4) diplomatic and consular programs; (5) the Special Inspector General for Iraq Reconstruction; (6) educational and cultural exchange programs; (7) contributions to international peacekeeping activities; (8) international broadcasting operations and capital improvements; and (9) salaries and expenses of the Department of the Treasury.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for further hurricane disaster relief and recovery for: (1) DOA for the Working Capital Fund, the Agricultural Research Service, and emergency watershed protection program; (2) DOD for military personnel, O&M, procurement, Defense Working Capital Funds and the National Defense Sealift Fund, commissary trust funds, and the Defense Health Program; (3) the Army Corps of Engineers for construction, flood control, and coastal emergencies; (4) the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for the Office of Inspector General, customs and border protection, and construction; (5) the U.S. Coast Guard for operating expenses and acquisition, construction, and improvements; (6) the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) for administrative and regional operations, preparedness, mitigation, response and recovery, disaster relief, and the Disaster Assistance Direct Loan Program; (7) the Department of the Interior for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, the National Park Service, the U.S. Geological Survey, and Minerals Management Service; (8) the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) for environmental programs and management and the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Program; (9) DOA for the National Forest System; (10) DOD for military construction; (11) the Department of Veterans Affairs for construction, major projects; (12) the Department of Justice (DOJ) for salaries and expenses; (13) the Department of Commerce (DOC) for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration; (14) the Small Business Administration (SBA) for the Disaster Loans Program; (15) the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) for the community development fund; and (16) the General Services Administration (GSA) for the Federal Buildings Fund.

Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act for Defense, the Global War on Terror, and Hurricane Recovery, 2006 - Title I: Global War on Terror Supplemental Appropriations - Chapter 1: Department of Agriculture - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2006 for the global war on terror to the Department of Agriculture (DOA) for P.L. 480 title II grants (emergency and non-emergency food assistance).

Chapter 2: Department of Justice - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Justice (DOJ) for salaries and expenses of United States Attorneys, the U.S. Marshals Service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of State and related agencies for: (1) diplomatic and consular programs; (2) the Office of Inspector General; (3) educational and cultural exchange programs; (4) contributions for international peacekeeping activities; and (5) international broadcasting operations.

Chapter 3: Department of Defense - Military - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Defense (DOD) for: (1) military personnel; (2) operation and maintenance (O&M); (3) the Afghanistan Security Forces Fund; (4) the Iraq Security Forces Fund; (5) the Iraq Freedom Fund; (6) the Joint Improvised Explosive Device Defeat Fund; (7) procurement; (8) research, development, test and evaluation (RDT&E); (9) Defense Working Capital Funds; (10) the Defense Health Program; (11) drug interdiction and counter-drug activities related to Afghanistan and Central Asia; (12) the Office of the Inspector General; and (13) the Intelligence Community Management Account.

(Sec. 1301) Authorizes the Secretary of Defense (Secretary, for purposes of title I), in the national interest, to transfer between appropriations up to $2 billion of the funds made available to DOD in this Chapter. Requires congressional notification of each transfer.

(Sec. 1302) Amends the Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2006 to increase from $3.75 billion to $4.35 billion the amount of DOD working capital funds authorized to be transferred by the Secretary for military functions.

(Sec. 1303) Authorizes the Secretary to transfer to DOD appropriations up to $5.85 million from the Defense Cooperation Account.

(Sec. 1304) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2006 to increase the amount authorized for U.S. contributions to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).

(Sec. 1305) Authorizes the use of specified DOD funds for support for counter-drug activities of the governments of Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Kyrgyzstan.

(Sec. 1306) Prohibits the total amount of advance billings rendered or imposed for all DOD working capital funds in FY2006 from exceeding $1.2 billion.

(Sec. 1307) Authorizes the use of specified DOD funds to fund the Commander's Emergency Response Program and for a similar program to assist the people of Afghanistan.

(Sec. 1309) Prohibits funds appropriated in this Chapter from being used to finance programs or activities denied by Congress in FY2005 and 2006 appropriations to DOD or to initiate a procurement or RDT&E new start program without prior written notification to the congressional defense committees.

(Sec. 1310) Changes from May 11, 2005, to August 31, 2005, the eligibility date for retroactive payment of the additional death gratuity for survivors and dependents of certain deceased military personnel authorized under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2006.

(Sec. 1311) Directs that the Interim Voting Assistance System be continued with respect to all DOD personnel and families covered by the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act. Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense committees on the status of the program. Provides funding.

Chapter 4: Bilateral Economic Assistance - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) for: (1) the Child Survival and Health Programs Fund; (2) development assistance; (3) international disaster and famine assistance; and (4) USAID operating expenses.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for: (1) the Economic Support Fund; (2) the Democracy Fund; (3) international narcotics control and law enforcement; (4) migration and refugee assistance; (5) the United States Emergency Refugee and Migration Assistance Fund; (6) international affairs technical assistance; and (7) peacekeeping operations.

(Sec. 1401) Amends the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act for Defense and for the Reconstruction of Iraq and Afghanistan, 2004 to revise allocation amounts appropriated under the Iraq Relief and Reconstruction Fund. Provides for the obligation of supervision and administrative costs with respect to such Fund.

(Sec. 1404) Amends the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 2006 to prohibit the obligation or expenditure of funds appropriated for assistance to the Palestinian Authority unless the Secretary of State determines, and reports to the congressional appropriations committees, that the Palestinian Authority has: (1) publicly acknowledged Israel's right to exist as a Jewish state; (2) renounced violence; and (3) accepted and is adhering to all previous diplomatic agreements and understandings with the U.S. government, the government of Israel, and the international community.

(Sec. 1405) Rescinds specified funds available in certain prior Acts for the Export-Import Bank of the United States for tied-aid grants.

Chapter 5: Department of Homeland Security - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Homeland Security for operating expenses of the U.S. Coast Guard.

Chapter 6: Department of Defense - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to DOD for military construction.

Chapter 7: Department of the Treasury - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of the Treasury for salaries and expenses of departmental offices.

Title II: Further Hurricane Disaster Relief and Recovery - Chapter 1: Department of Agriculture - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2006 for necessary expenses related to the consequences of Hurricane Katrina and other hurricanes of the 2005 season for the Department of Agriculture for: (1) executive operations; (2) the Agricultural Research Service; (3) the Farm Service Agency; (4) the Natural Resources Conservation Service's (NRCS) Emergency Watershed Protection Program; and (5) rural development.

(Sec. 2101) Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to provide financial and technical assistance for NRCS's Emergency Watershed Protection Program.

(Sec. 2102) Authorizes the Chief of NRCS to enter into agreements with organizations or state or local governments affected by such hurricanes that provide for NRCS to donate used vehicles.

(Sec. 2103) Authorizes the Secretary to continue to use its emergency rural development authority in hurricane-affected areas for 24 additional months.

(Sec. 2104) Transfers specified funds under the Farm Service Agency's Emergency Conservation Program to the Department of Commerce's National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) for activities involving oysters.

(Sec. 2105) Repeals provisions of the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico and Pandemic Influenza, 2006 regarding assistance to oyster producers.

(Sec. 2106) Appropriates funds for rural housing needs in the most impacted and distressed areas related to the consequences of the hurricanes (prioritizing the funding of projects within a state based on the priorities identified by each state's governor).

Chapter 2: Departments of Justice and Commerce - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) DOJ for Office of the Inspector General salaries and expenses, general legal activities and U.S. Attorneys salaries and expenses, and for Office of Justice Programs state and local law enforcement assistance; (2) the Department of Commerce for NOAA operations, research, and facilities and for procurement, acquisition, and construction; (3) the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) for exploration capabilities for the Stennis Space Center; and (4) the Small Business Administration's (SBA) disaster loans program account.

Chapter 3: Department of Defense - Military - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the 2005 hurricanes for the Department of Defense (DOD) for: (1) personnel; (2) operations and maintenance; (3) procurement and shipbuilding and conversion; (4) research, development, test, and evaluation; (5) Defense Working Capital Funds and the National Defense Sealift Fund; (6) General Fund Payment, Surcharge Collections, Sales of Commissary Stores, Defense; (7) the Defense Health Program; and (8) the Office of the Inspector General.

(Sec. 2301) Authorizes the Secretary of Defense, to ensure the appropriate allocation of DOD funds, to transfer up to $75 million of such funds between appropriations, subject to a reporting requirement.

(Sec. 2302) Prohibits the use of such funds to finance programs denied by Congress in FY2005 and FY2006 DOD appropriations or to initiate a procurement or research, development, test, and evaluation new start program without prior written notification to the congressional defense committees.

(Sec. 2303) Authorizes the use of funds for Shipbuilding and Conversion, Navy, to pay the costs of any business disruption incurred by a ship construction contractor with respect to facilities or businesses located in the Hurricane Katrina Disaster Area by reason of Hurricane Katrina.

Chapter 4: Department of Defense - Civil - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of the Army for: (1) investigations for flood hazard analyses and technical studies related to the consequences of Hurricane Katrina and other disasters; (2) construction to reduce the risk of storm damage to the greater New Orleans metropolitan area by restoring the surrounding wetlands; (3) operations and maintenance to dredge navigation channels and repair other Corps projects related to the consequences of the hurricanes; and (4) flood control and coastal emergencies for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes.

Chapter 5: Department of Homeland Security - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Homeland Security for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) Customs and Border Protection; (2) the U.S. Coast Guard; and (3) the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).

(Sec. 2501) Permits FEMA to provide funds to a state or local government or assume an existing agreement from such governmental unit to pay for utility costs resulting from the provision of temporary housing units to evacuees from the hurricanes.

(Sec. 2502) Amends the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2006, to increase appropriations for the National Flood Insurance Fund.

(Sec. 2503) Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to consider the costs for alternative housing pilot programs in the areas hardest hit by the hurricanes to be eligible under the FEMA Individual Assistance Program.

Chapter 6: Departments of Agriculture and the Interior, Environmental Protection Agency - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of the Interior for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; (2) the National Park Service; (3) the U.S. Geological Survey; and (4) the Minerals Management Service.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes to: (1) the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA); and (2) the Department of Agriculture for the National Forest System.

Chapter 7: Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Labor for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) the Employment and Training Administration; and (2) the Office of Inspector General.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) the Human Resources and Services Administration; (2) the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC); and (3) the Office of Inspector General.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Education for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) the Office of Inspector General; and (2) hurricane education recovery.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes to: (1) the Corporation for National and Community Service, including for the Civilian Community Corps; and (2) the Social Security Administration's Office of Inspector General.

(Sec. 2701) Directs the Secretary of Education to establish an Education Relief Loan Program that provides for long-term, low-interest direct loans to eligible postsecondary educational institutions for losses incurred on or after August 28, 2005, resulting from the impact of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita and for recovery initiatives of such institutions.

(Sec. 2702) Authorizes the Secretary to waive or modify statutory or regulatory provisions related to historically Black college and university capital financing under the Higher Education Act of 1965 in connection with a Gulf hurricane disaster to ensure that: (1) the calculation of financing need for an affected institution is modified to reflect any changes in the institution's financial condition as a result of the disaster; and (2) an affected institution that was not receiving assistance under that Act before the disaster is eligible to apply for capital financing to assist in institutional recovery.

(Sec. 2703) Allows funds available to the Mississippi Institutes of Higher Learning to be used to support activities authorized by the Higher Education Act.

Chapter 8: Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) DOD for military construction for the Navy, Air Force, Army National Guard, Air National Guard, and Naval Reserve; (2) the Department of Veterans Affairs; and (3) planning, design, and construction of a new Armed Forces Retirement Home in Gulfport, Mississippi.

(Sec. 2801) Waives the federal contribution limit for an armory or readiness center for projects for which funds are appropriated in this chapter.

(Sec. 2802) Rescinds and transfers funds for the Department of Veterans Affairs, Veterans Health Administration, and Medical Services.

(Sec. 2803) Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to clean up and transfer all land parcels of the Department's land in Gulfport to the city of Gulfport.

(Sec. 2804) Authorizes the Secretary to obligate and expend major projects construction funds to purchase a site for, and the new construction, restoration, or replacement of, the Department's Medical Centers in New Orleans, Louisiana, and Biloxi, Mississippi.

(Sec. 2805) Transfers funds to the Armed Forces Retirement Home major construction account.

Chapter 9: Departments of Transportation and Housing and Urban Development - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Transportation for: (1) the Federal Highway Administration's Emergency Relief Program; (2) the Federal Transit Administration; and (3) the Federal Railroad Administration.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) Tenant-Based Rental Assistance; and (2) the Community Development Fund.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the General Services Administration (GSA) related to the consequences of the hurricanes for the Federal Buildings Fund.

Title III: Emergency Agricultural Disaster Assistance Act of 2006 - Emergency Agricultural Disaster Assistance Act of 2006 - (Sec. 3002) Defines specified terms.

Defines "hurricane-affected county" as a county covered by a natural disaster designation related to Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, or Wilma, or a related condition, and each county contiguous to such county.

Subtitle A: Agricultural Production Losses - (Sec. 3011) Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to provide emergency financial assistance to eligible agricultural producers (other than sugarcane and sugar beet producers) who have incurred qualifying: (1) 2005 crop losses due to weather or related conditions (including crop disease, insects, and delayed harvest); and (2) 2006 crop losses due to flooding in California and Hawaii that occurred prior to the date of enactment of this Act and for which a petition for a disaster designation has been filed with the Secretary.

(Sec. 3012) Directs the Secretary to provide: (1) payments through the 2002 livestock compensation program for 2005 and 2006 livestock disaster losses that occurred prior to enactment of this Act (including wildfire disaster losses in Texas and other states); (2) livestock indemnity payments for 2005 and 2006 livestock disaster losses that occurred prior to enactment of this Act (including wildfire disaster losses in Texas and other states), including losses due to hurricanes, floods, wildfires, and anthrax; and (3) indemnity payments to poultry producers in hurricane-affected counties, and for 2006 ewe lamb replacement and retention.

(Sec. 3013) Directs the Secretary to provide compensation for certain owners of flooded crop and grazing land in North Dakota.

(Sec. 3014) Directs the Secretary to provide: (1) sugarcane and sugar beet disaster assistance for qualifying producers and first processors in Louisiana counties designated as disaster areas due to Hurricanes Katrina or Rita, or related conditions; (2) qualifying sugar beet producers who suffered 2005 production losses; (3) sugarcane and sugar beet assistance for qualifying producers and first processors in Florida for 2005 losses in hurricane-affected counties due to hurricanes, floods, rain, or storms; (4) assistance to sugarcane growers in Texas by making a payment to the Rio Grande Valley Sugar Growers for additional Baton Rouge demurrage costs and raw sugar transportation and storage costs resulting from 2005 hurricanes, flooding, and related conditions; and (5) assistance to sugarcane growers in Hawaii for an agricultural transportation cooperative.

(Sec. 3015) Directs the Secretary to provide assistance to specialty and nursery crop producers in hurricane-affected counties.

(Sec. 3016) Directs the Secretary to provide assistance to dairy producers for production and spoilage losses in hurricane-affected counties.

(Sec. 3017) Directs the Secretary to provide assistance to producers and first handlers of cottonseed.

(Sec. 3018) Reduces assistance under this subtitle by amounts for the same or similar loss under: (1) the Department of Defense, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico, and Pandemic Influenza Act, 2006; or (2) an agricultural disaster assistance provision contained in the Secretary's announcement of January 26, 2006.

Subtitle B: Supplemental Nutrition and Agricultural Economic Disaster Assistance - (Sec. 3021) Directs the Secretary to make grants to eligible states for: (1) agricultural promotion, with set-asides for Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia; and (2) a state's share of the total value of U.S. specialty crop, livestock, and dairy production.

(Sec. 3022) Directs the Secretary to make supplemental economic loss payments under a specified rate to producers who received crop year 2005 commodity assistance.

(Sec. 3023) Reduces assistance under this subtitle by amounts for the same or similar loss under: (1) the Department of Defense, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico, and Pandemic Influenza Act, 2006; or (2) an agricultural disaster assistance provision contained in the Secretary's announcement of January 26, 2006.

Subtitle C: Forestry - (Sec. 3031) Directs the Secretary to provide assistance to: (1) tree producers (including Christmas, potted, ornamental, and nursery trees, bushes and shrubs, and vines) in hurricane-affected counties; and (2) fruit and tree nut producers in hurricane-affected counties for site preparation, replacement, rehabilitation, and pruning.

Subtitle D: Conservation - (Sec. 3041) Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) provide financial and technical assistance to remove debris and animal carcasses that could adversely affect health and safety on non-federal land in hurricane-affected counties; and (2) use direct check-writing practices and electronic transfers to provide financial and technical assistance under the emergency watershed protection program in hurricane-affected counties.

(Sec. 3042) Directs the Secretary to make additional emergency watershed protection funds available for emergency measures identified by the Natural Resources Conservation Service.

(Sec. 3043) Directs the Secretary to make additional emergency conservation funds available for emergency measures identified by the Farm Service Agency.

Subtitle E: Farm Service Agency - (Sec. 3051) Directs the Secretary to hire additional state and county Farm Service Agency personnel to assist in agricultural disaster and economic assistance programs.

Subtitle F: Miscellaneous - (Sec. 3061) Authorizes the Secretary to provide immunizations to Department of Agriculture employees involved in direct recovery work in hurricane-affected counties.

(Sec. 3062) Authorizes the Secretary to provide emergency conservation assistance in hurricane-affected counties without regard to wetlands-related provisions.

(Sec. 3063) Directs the Secretary to use Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC) funds, facilities, and authorities to carry out this title, which shall remain available until expended.

Subtitle G: Emergency Designation - (Sec. 3071) Designates amounts provided under this title as an emergency requirement.

Title IV: Drought Emergency Assistance - (Sec. 4001) Appropriates, in addition to any other funds under this Act, emergency drought assistance funds for: (1) the Army Corps of Engineers; and (2) the Bureau of Reclamation (Department of the Interior).

(Sec. 4003) Designates amounts provided under this title as an emergency requirement.

Title V: Port Security Enhancements - Appropriates funds for port security enhancements for: (1) customs and border protection for salaries and expenses; (2) the U.S. Coast Guard's operating expenses; (3) the Office for Domestic Preparedness for state and local programs; and (4) the Domestic Nuclear Detection Office for research, development, acquisition, and operations.

Title VI: Pandemic Flu - Appropriates funds to the Department of Health and Human Services for the Public Health and Social Services Emergency Fund to prepare for and respond to an influenza pandemic.

Title VII: General Provisions and Technical Corrections - (Sec. 7002) Makes certain funds, otherwise available for Paul Coverdell Forensic Sciences Improvement Grants under the Department of Justice Appropriations Act, 2006, available to the Attorney General for a specified study of forensic science.

(Sec. 7003) Deems the conference report accompanying the Science, State, Justice, Commerce, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006 to require certain amounts made available for the Mitchell Institute in Portland, Maine, to be for the science and engineering education endowment.

(Sec. 7004) Amends the same Act to shift funds earmarked for the Clark County Department of Aviation, Las Vegas, Nevada, for the international air trade show to the University of Nevada Las Vegas for the same purpose.

(Sec. 7005) Deems funds appropriated or made available by the transfer of funds in or pursuant to this Act for intelligence activities to be specifically authorized by Congress for purposes of the National Security Act of 1947.

(Sec. 7007) Requires certain funds provided in the Department of Defense, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico, and Pandemic Influenza Act, 2006 for the Louisiana hurricane protection study to be provided at full federal expense.

(Sec. 7008) Amends the same Act to direct the Corps of Engineers to accelerate completion of any study or any unconstructed portion of the Mississippi River and Tributaries project for the flood and storm damage reduction projects in the south Louisiana area.

Designates the amount provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement pursuant to H.Con.Res. 95, 109th Congress (FY2006 congressional budget).

(Sec. 7009) Earmarks certain funds appropriated in the same Act for the repair, construction, or provision of measures or structures necessary to protect, restore, or increase wetlands to prevent saltwater intrusion or storm surge.

Designates the amount provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement pursuant to the FY2006 congressional budget.

(Sec. 7010) Amends the Water Resources Development Act of 1996 to require the Secretary of the Army to extend from six to seven years the national shoreline erosion control development and demonstration program.

Increases the authorization of appropriations for such program from $21 million to $25 million.

(Sec. 7011) Amends the Reclamation States Emergency Drought Relief Act of 1991 to extend the drought program through FY2005-FY2010.

Continues the authorization of appropriations for such Act for FY2006-FY2010.

(Sec. 7012) Prohibits the expenditure of any funds to prevent or limit any reprogramming of funds for a project to be carried out by the Corps of Engineers using energy and water development appropriations, based on whether the project was included in the President's budget or is otherwise proposed by the President or considered part of it by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), if the project received funds in an Act making such appropriations.

(Sec. 7013) Prohibits the use of funds during FY2006 or before April 1, 2007, for any payment on bonds issued by the Administrator of the Bonneville Power Administration (Administrator) or for an appropriated Federal Columbia River Power System investment, if the payment is both: (1) greater, during any fiscal year, than the payments calculated in the Administrator's rate hearing using the repayment method used to establish such rates as in effect on February 6, 2006; and (2) based or conditioned on the actual or expected net secondary power sales receipts of the Administrator.

(Sec. 7014) Rescinds $3.96 million of funds appropriated to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for "Screening Coordination and Operations."

Appropriates the same additional amount for the DHS Office of the Secretary and Executive Management.

(Sec. 7015) Appropriates additional funds to the Department of the Interior for "U.S. Geological Survey, Surveys, Investigations, and Research," to remain available until expended, for assistance with assessments of critical reservoirs and dams, including the monitoring of dam structure.

Designates the amount provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement pursuant to the FY2006 congressional budget.

(Sec. 7016) Amends the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to extend from June 30, 2006, through FY2007 payment of the current reclamation fee by operators of coal mining operations for deposit in the fund under the Act (after which time, as under current law, the fee is to be established at a new rate to continue to provide for such deposit).

(Sec. 7017) Prohibits the expenditure of funds made available under this Act or under the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006, for any activity that: (1) is related to carrying out Order 09-2006 of the Secretary of Labor; or (2) transfers the Office of Job Corps but does not establish it as a single office within the Office of the Secretary that retains all staff, functions and authorities related to carrying out the Job Corps requirements of the Workforce Investment Act of 1998.

(Sec. 7018) Appropriates additional funds through FY2007 under "Department of Labor, Mine Safety and Health Administration, Salaries and Expenses" for the inspection of coal mines.

Designates the amount provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement pursuant to the FY2006 congressional budget.

(Sec. 7019) Appropriates additional funds through FY2007 for "Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Disease Control, Research and Training" to carry out the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 for research to develop mine safety technology including grants and contracts.

Designates the amount provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement pursuant to the FY2006 congressional budget.

(Sec. 7020) Amends the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006, under "Railroad Retirement Board, Dual Benefits Payments Account," to revise the formula for payment of additional funds to the Dual Benefits Payments Account.

(Sec. 7021) Amends the same Act to delay from June 30 until December 30, 2006, the alternative effective date for applicability of certain federal transportation safety regulations to any Head Start agency or its designee that provides transportation services for children enrolled in a Head Start or Early Head Start program, if that agency or designee places such children in child restraint systems.

(Sec. 7022) Amends the Military Construction Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2006 (Public Law 109-163) to increase the authorization of appropriations a National Security Agency installations in Augusta, Georgia, and in Kunia, Hawaii.

(Sec. 7024) Amends the Military Construction Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2002, as amended by the Military Construction Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005, to increase the acreage that the Secretary of the Navy is authorized to acquire in a specified land acquisition in Perquimans County, North Carolina.

(Sec. 7025) Amends the Transportation, Treasury, Housing and Urban Development, the Judiciary, the District of Columbia, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006 to authorize the Department of Transportation (DOT) Office of Intelligence, Security, and Emergency Response to assess and enter into reimbursable agreements with the modal administrations for services necessary to carry out emergency preparedness or emergency response activities.

(Sec. 7026) Amends the Department of Defense, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico, and Pandemic Influenza Act, 2006, under "Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration, Emergency Relief Program," to increase the earmark for funds to repair and reconstruct the I-10 bridge spanning New Orleans and Slidell, Louisiana.

(Sec. 7027) Prohibits the use of funds to issue or implement a decision on the Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (70 Fed. Reg. 67389) that proposes to change DOT's long-standing interpretation of "actual control" of an airline for purposes of the federal definition of U.S. citizens (regarding air commerce and safety), issue any final rule, or make any fitness determination that would change such long-standing interpretation concerning what constitutes such "actual control" of an airline, or to submit a final rule to Congress that would change that interpretation.

(Sec. 7028) Deems funds appropriated for intelligence activities, or made available by the transfer of funds, by this or other specified Acts, to be specifically authorized by Congress for intelligence activities purposes of the National Security Act of 1947, as amended, during FY2006 until the enactment of the Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2006.

(Sec. 7029) Amends the Department of Transportation Appropriations Act, 2006, in the Transportation, Treasury, Housing and Urban Development, the Judiciary, the District of Columbia, and Independent Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006, under "Department of the Treasury, Departmental Offices, Salaries and Expenses," to exclude from the limitation on appropriations for travel expenses any travel performed by officials in the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence and the Office of International Affairs.

(Sec. 7030) Amends the statement of managers accompanying the conference report on H.R. 2673 under "Community Development Fund" to require that funds appropriated for: (1) the Minnesota Corn Growers Association in Shakopee, Minnesota, be used to upgrade an existing facility in lieu of constructing a new one; and (2) the City of Macon, Georgia, be used for the construction or development of a drivers' license facility in lieu of renovation of the historic Coca-Cola building.

Amends the statement of managers accompanying the conference report on Public Law 109-115 under "Community Development Fund" to require that funds be appropriated to the Mark Twain Community Alliance (instead of the Mark Twain Neighborhood Association) for capital improvements in St. Louis.

(Sec. 7031) Authorizes the Administrator of General Services to convey, without consideration, ownership and jurisdiction (custody, accountability, and control) of specified property in Divide County, North Dakota, to the City of Crosby, North Dakota.

Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act for Defense, the Global War on Terror, and Hurricane Recovery, 2006 - Title I: Global War on Terror Supplemental Appropriations - Chapter 1: Department of Agriculture - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2006 for the global war on terror to the Department of Agriculture (USDA) for P.L. 480 title II grants (emergency and non-emergency food assistance).

Chapter 2: Department of Justice - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Justice (DOJ) for salaries and expenses of United States Attorneys, the U.S. Marshals Service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of State and related agencies for: (1) diplomatic and consular programs; (2) the Office of Inspector General; (3) educational and cultural exchange programs; (4) contributions for international peacekeeping activities; and (5) international broadcasting operations.

(Sec. 1203) Amends the Foreign Service Act of 1980 to authorize the Secretary of State (Secretary, for purposes of this section) to waive annuity limitations on foreign service agents reemployed on a temporary basis on a case-by-case basis, or to grant such authority to the head of an executive agency if: (1) and for so long as, such waiver is necessary due to an emergency involving a direct threat to life or property or other unusual circumstances; or (2) the annuitant is employed in a position for which there is exceptional difficulty in recruiting or retaining a qualified employee. Terminates the waiver authority on October 1, 2008.

Amends the Department of State Basic Authorities Act of 1956 to provide an identical annuity limitation waiver (with the same termination date) for the Secretary with respect to temporarily reemployed annuitants in a position in the Department of State for which there is exceptional difficulty in recruiting or retaining, or when a temporary emergency hiring need exists.

Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to provide for the same annuity limitation waiver (with the same termination date) for the Administrator for the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) with respect to temporarily reemployed annuitants in a position in USAID for which there is exceptional difficulty in recruiting or retaining, or when a temporary emergency hiring need exists.

Requires a report from the Secretary to specified congressional committees on the exercise of the waiver authorities under this section.

Amends the Foreign Service Act of 1980 to authorize the Secretary to order a member of the Foreign Service to take a leave of absence upon the member's completion of 12 (currently, 18) months of continuous service abroad.

Authorizes the Secretary to provide, during any fiscal year, accommodation and subsistence to personnel in Iraq and Afghanistan for whom the Chief of Mission is responsible.

(Sec. 1204) Prohibits the use of funds under this title to establish permanent U.S. military bases in Iraq, or to exercise U.S. control over Iraqi oil infrastructure or resources.

Chapter 3: Department of Defense - Military - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Defense (DOD) for: (1) military personnel; (2) operation and maintenance (O&M); (3) the Afghanistan Security Forces Fund; (4) the Iraq Security Forces Fund; (5) the Iraq Freedom Fund; (6) the Joint Improvised Explosive Device Defeat Fund; (7) procurement; (8) research, development, test and evaluation (RDT&E); (9) Defense Working Capital Funds; (10) the Defense Health Program; (11) drug interdiction and counter-drug activities related to Afghanistan and Central Asia; (12) the Office of the Inspector General; and (13) the Intelligence Community Management Account.

(Sec. 1301) Authorizes the Secretary of Defense (Secretary, for purposes of this Chapter), in the national interest, to transfer between appropriations up to $2 billion of the funds made available to DOD in this Chapter. Requires congressional notification of each transfer.

(Sec. 1302) Amends the Department of Defense Appropriations Act, 2006 to increase from $3.75 billion to $4.35 billion the amount of DOD working capital funds authorized to be transferred by the Secretary for military functions.

(Sec. 1303) Authorizes the Secretary to transfer to DOD appropriations up to $5.85 million from the Defense Cooperation Account.

(Sec. 1304) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2006 to increase the amount authorized for U.S. contributions to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).

(Sec. 1305) Authorizes the use of specified DOD funds for support for counter-drug activities of the governments of Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Kyrgyzstan.

(Sec. 1306) Prohibits the total amount of advance billings rendered or imposed for all DOD working capital funds in FY2006 from exceeding $1.2 billion.

(Sec. 1307) Authorizes the use of specified DOD funds to fund the Commander's Emergency Response Program and for a similar program to assist the people of Afghanistan.

(Sec. 1309) Prohibits funds appropriated in this Chapter from being used to finance programs or activities denied by Congress in FY2005 and 2006 appropriations to DOD or to initiate a procurement or RDT&E new start program without prior written notification to the congressional defense committees.

(Sec. 1310) Changes from May 11, 2005, to August 31, 2005, the eligibility date for retroactive payment of the additional death gratuity for survivors and dependents of certain deceased military personnel authorized under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2006.

(Sec. 1311) Directs that the Interim Voting Assistance System be continued with respect to all DOD personnel and families covered by the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act. Requires a report from the Secretary to the defense committees on the status of the program. Provides funding.

(Sec. 1312) Reservists Pay Security Act of 2006 - Amends federal employment provisions to entitle federal employees who are absent from their positions while serving on active duty in the Armed Forces during a war or national emergency to receive the amount of their basic federal pay which, when taken together with their military pay and allowances, is no less than the amount of pay they would have earned if there had been no interruption in their civilian employment. Expands the reemployment rights of such employees.

(Sec. 1313) Expresses the sense of the Senate that: (1) any request for funds for a fiscal year after 2007 for ongoing military operations in Afghanistan and Iraq should be included in the annual budget of the President submitted to Congress; (2) such request should include a detailed justification of anticipated uses of the funds; and (3) any funds provided in a fiscal year for ongoing military operations overseas should be provided in appropriations Acts through appropriations to specific accounts.

(Sec. 1314) Increases by a specified amount the amount appropriated in this Chapter for defense-wide O&M funds and made available for Cooperative Threat Reduction.

Chapter 4: Bilateral Economic Assistance - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) for: (1) the Child Survival and Health Programs Fund; (2) development assistance; (3) international disaster and famine assistance; and (4) USAID operating expenses.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for: (1) the Economic Support Fund; (2) the Democracy Fund; (3) international narcotics control and law enforcement; (4) migration and refugee assistance; (5) the United States Emergency Refugee and Migration Assistance Fund; (6) international affairs technical assistance; and (7) peacekeeping operations.

(Sec. 1401) Amends the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act for Defense and for the Reconstruction of Iraq and Afghanistan, 2004 to revise allocation amounts appropriated under the Iraq Relief and Reconstruction Fund. Provides for the obligation of supervision and administrative costs with respect to such Fund.

(Sec. 1404) Amends the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 2006 to prohibit the obligation or expenditure of funds appropriated for assistance to the Palestinian Authority unless the Secretary of State determines, and reports to the congressional appropriations committees, that the Palestinian Authority has: (1) publicly acknowledged Israel's right to exist as a Jewish state; (2) renounced violence; and (3) accepted and is adhering to all previous diplomatic agreements and understandings with the U.S. government, the government of Israel, and the international community. Authorizes the President to waive such requirements if: (1) it is in the U.S. national security interest to provide such assistance; and (2) the President of the Palestinian Authority, that President's party, and its independent agencies are not effectively controlled by Hamas or any other foreign terrorist organization. Requires the President to provide to specified congressional committees a justification of such waiver authority.

(Sec. 1405) Rescinds specified funds available in certain prior Acts for the Export-Import Bank of the United States for tied-aid grants.

(Sec. 1406) Authorizes the head of an agency to provide to an employee on official duty in Iraq or Afghanistan allowances, benefits, and gratuities comparable to those provided by the Secretary of State to members of the Foreign Service.

(Sec. 1407) Earmarks specified funds from the Economic Support Fund for supporting specified democracy assistance programs in Iraq. Directs the President to include in each report to Congress under the United States Policy in Iraq Act a report on the extent to which funds appropriated in this Act support a short- and long-term strategy to promote and develop democracy in Iraq.

(Sec. 1408) Rescinds specified funds from the Economic Support Fund.

Chapter 5: Department of Homeland Security - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Homeland Security for operating expenses of the U.S. Coast Guard.

Chapter 6: Department of Defense - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to: (1) DOD for military construction; and (2) the Veterans Health Administration for medical services.

Chapter 7: Department of the Treasury - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of the Treasury for salaries and expenses of departmental offices.

Title II: Further Hurricane Disaster Relief and Recovery - Chapter 1: Department of Agriculture - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2006 for necessary expenses related to the consequences of Hurricane Katrina and other hurricanes of the 2005 season for the Department of Agriculture for: (1) executive operations; (2) the Agricultural Research Service; (3) the Farm Service Agency; (4) the Natural Resources Conservation Service's (NRCS) Emergency Watershed Protection Program; and (5) rural development.

(Sec. 2101) Authorizes the Secretary of Agriculture to provide financial and technical assistance for NRCS's Emergency Watershed Protection Program.

(Sec. 2102) Authorizes the Chief of NRCS to enter into agreements with organizations or state or local governments affected by such hurricanes that provide for NRCS to donate used vehicles.

(Sec. 2103) Authorizes the Secretary to continue to use its emergency rural development authority in hurricane-affected areas for 24 additional months.

(Sec. 2104) Transfers specified funds under the Farm Service Agency's Emergency Conservation Program to the Department of Commerce's National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) for activities involving oysters.

(Sec. 2105) Repeals provisions of the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico and Pandemic Influenza, 2006 regarding assistance to oyster producers.

(Sec. 2106) Appropriates funds for rural housing needs in the most impacted and distressed areas related to the consequences of the hurricanes (prioritizing the funding of projects within a state based on the priorities identified by each state's governor).

(Sec. 2107) Directs that funds made available for the wildlife habitat incentive program remain available until expended to carry out obligations made for FY2001 and not be available for new obligations.

(Sec. 2108) Amends: (1) the Small Business Act to include within an “historically underutilized business zone” an area in which the President has declared a major disaster as a result of Hurricanes Katrina or Rita; and (2) the Small Business Competitive Demonstration Program Act of 1988 to make the Small Business Competitiveness Demonstration Program inapplicable to any contract related to relief or reconstruction from such hurricanes.

(Sec. 2109) Prohibits the use of funds appropriated by this Act that are made available for relief and recovery efforts related to hurricanes of the 2005 season from being used by an executive agency to enter into any federal contract exceeding $500,000 through the use of noncompetitive procedures.

Chapter 2: Departments of Justice and Commerce - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) DOJ for Office of the Inspector General salaries and expenses, general legal activities and U.S. Attorneys salaries and expenses, and for Office of Justice Programs state and local law enforcement assistance; (2) the Department of Commerce for NOAA operations, research, and facilities and for procurement, acquisition, and construction; (3) the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) for exploration capabilities for the Stennis Space Center; and (4) the Small Business Administration's (SBA) disaster loans program account.

(Sec. 2201) Directs the SBA Administrator to report to specified congressional committees: (1) by May 31, 2006, on the status of the SBA's disaster response plan for the 2006 Atlantic hurricane season; and (2) each month during the period of a presidentially declared disaster on the operation of the disaster loan program.

Chapter 3: Department of Defense - Military - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the 2005 hurricanes for the Department of Defense (DOD) for: (1) personnel; (2) operations and maintenance; (3) procurement and shipbuilding and conversion; (4) research, development, test, and evaluation; (5) Defense Working Capital Funds and the National Defense Sealift Fund; (6) General Fund Payment, Surcharge Collections, Sales of Commissary Stores, Defense; (7) the Defense Health Program; and (8) the Office of the Inspector General.

(Sec. 2301) Authorizes the Secretary of Defense, to ensure the appropriate allocation of DOD funds, to transfer up to $75 million of such funds between appropriations, subject to a reporting requirement.

(Sec. 2302) Prohibits the use of such funds to finance programs denied by Congress in FY2005 and FY2006 DOD appropriations or to initiate a procurement or research, development, test, and evaluation new start program without prior written notification to the congressional defense committees.

(Sec. 2303) Authorizes the use of funds for Shipbuilding and Conversion, Navy, to pay the costs of any business disruption incurred by a ship construction contractor with respect to facilities or businesses located in the Hurricane Katrina Disaster Area by reason of Hurricane Katrina.

Chapter 4: Department of Defense - Civil - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of the Army for necessary expenses related to the consequences of hurricanes of the 2005 season for: (1) investigations; (2) construction; (3) operations and maintenance to dredge navigation channels and repair other Corps projects; and (4) flood control and coastal emergencies.

(Sec. 2401) Makes funds available for the Secretary to provide for: (1) the removal of pumping stations in Jefferson and Orleans Parishes and realignment of drainage canals to direct interior flows to new permanent pump stations at Lake Pontchartrain; (2) repairs, replacements, modifications, and improvements of non-federal levees and associated protection measures in Terrebonne Parish and on the east bank of the Mississippi River in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana; and (3) armoring the hurricane and storm damage reduction system in south Louisiana. Requires the Secretary: (1) to submit a report detailing a modified plan regarding levels of protection for lower Plaquemines Parish; (2) to offer to enter into a contract with the National Academies to provide a report on the vertical depreciation of the system; and (3) acting through the Chief, to develop a comprehensive plan to deauthorize deep draft navigation on the Mississippi River-Gulf Outlet and address wetland losses.

Authorizes the use of unexpended funds for general remediation activities being conducted in the vicinity of the Tar Creek Superfund Site in northeastern Oklahoma and in Ottawa County, Oklahoma, to assist individuals and entities in removal from areas at risk of damage caused by land subsidence.

Chapter 5: Department of Homeland Security - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) Customs and Border Protection; (2) the U.S. Coast Guard; and (3) the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA).

Requires: (1) for states in which the President declared a major disaster on September 24, 2005, as a result of Hurricane Rita, each county or parish eligible for individual and public assistance to be treated equally for purposes of cost-share adjustments; (2) any charter school to be considered for reimbursement for Hurricane Katrina or Hurricane Rita damage; and (3) any privately owned facility that houses the charter school to reimburse FEMA for improvements or repairs to the facility if the charter school vacates the facility before the end of five years following construction, unless it is replaced by another charter school during that period.

Makes appropriations for the Disaster Assistance Direct Loan Program Account for the cost of direct loans to assist local governments affected by hurricanes of the 2005 season in providing essential services. Provides that the loan amount may be equal to not more than 50% of the annual operating budget of the local government in any case in which that government has suffered a loss of 25% or more in tax revenues due to Hurricane Katrina or Hurricane Rita. Provides that such loans may not be canceled.

(Sec. 2501) Permits FEMA to provide funds to a state or local government or assume an existing agreement from such governmental unit to pay for utility costs resulting from the provision of temporary housing units to evacuees from the hurricanes.

(Sec. 2502) Amends the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2006, to increase appropriations for the National Flood Insurance Fund.

(Sec. 2503) Directs the Secretary of Homeland Security to consider the costs for alternative housing pilot programs in the areas hardest hit by the hurricanes to be eligible under the FEMA Individual Assistance Program.

Chapter 6: Departments of Agriculture and the Interior, Environmental Protection Agency - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of the Interior for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; (2) the National Park Service; (3) the U.S. Geological Survey; and (4) the Minerals Management Service.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes to: (1) the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA); and (2) the Department of Agriculture for the National Forest System.

Chapter 7: Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Labor for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) the Employment and Training Administration; and (2) the Office of Inspector General.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) the Human Resources and Services Administration; (2) the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC); and (3) the Office of Inspector General.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Education for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) the Office of Inspector General; and (2) hurricane education recovery. Makes specified funds available to the Department until December 31, 2006, under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (ESEA), for allocations to states for necessary expenses in the 2006-2007 academic year related to the consequences of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Requires: (1) funds to be allocated to each eligible state educational agency based on its relative share of displaced students; and (2) each state educational agency to make 100% of funds available to local educational agencies on the basis of each such agency's relative share of displaced students.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes to: (1) the Corporation for National and Community Service, including for the Civilian Community Corps; and (2) the Social Security Administration's Office of Inspector General.

(Sec. 2701) Directs the Secretary of Education to establish an Education Relief Loan Program that provides for long-term, low-interest direct loans to eligible postsecondary educational institutions for losses incurred on or after August 28, 2005, resulting from the impact of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita and for recovery initiatives of such institutions.

(Sec. 2702) Authorizes the Secretary to waive or modify statutory or regulatory provisions related to historically Black college and university capital financing under the Higher Education Act of 1965 in connection with a Gulf hurricane disaster to ensure that: (1) the calculation of financing need for an affected institution is modified to reflect any changes in the institution's financial condition as a result of the disaster; and (2) an affected institution that was not receiving assistance under that Act before the disaster is eligible to apply for capital financing to assist in institutional recovery.

(Sec. 2703) Allows funds available to the Mississippi Institutes of Higher Learning to be used to support activities authorized by the Higher Education Act.

(Sec. 2704) Transfers specified FEMA disaster relief funds to the Social Security Administration for necessary expenses and losses related to the consequences of 2005 hurricanes.

Chapter 8: Departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations for necessary expenses related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) DOD for military construction for the Navy, Air Force, Army National Guard, Air National Guard, and Naval Reserve; (2) the Department of Veterans Affairs; and (3) planning, design, and construction of a new Armed Forces Retirement Home in Gulfport, Mississippi.

(Sec. 2801) Waives the federal contribution limit for an armory or readiness center for projects for which funds are appropriated in this chapter.

(Sec. 2802) Rescinds and transfers funds for the Department of Veterans Affairs, Veterans Health Administration, and Medical Services.

(Sec. 2803) Directs the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to clean up and transfer all land parcels of the Department's land in Gulfport to the city of Gulfport.

(Sec. 2804) Authorizes the Secretary to obligate and expend major projects construction funds to purchase a site for, and the new construction, restoration, or replacement of, the Department's Medical Centers in New Orleans, Louisiana, and Biloxi, Mississippi.

(Sec. 2805) Transfers funds to the Armed Forces Retirement Home major construction account for the planning, design, and construction of a new Armed Forces Retirement Home in Gulfport.

Chapter 9: Departments of Transportation and Housing and Urban Development - Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Transportation (DOT) for: (1) the Federal Highway Administration's Emergency Relief Program; (2) the Federal Transit Administration; and (3) the Federal Railroad Administration.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) related to the consequences of the hurricanes for: (1) Tenant-Based Rental Assistance; and (2) the Community Development Fund. Makes funds available for 4,500 project-based vouchers for supportive housing units for persons with disabilities, elderly families, or previously homeless individuals and families.

Makes emergency supplemental appropriations to: (1) the Election Assistance Commission to make discretionary payments to states affected by 2005 hurricanes to restore and replace supplies, materials, records, equipment, and technology used in the administration of federal elections and to ensure the full participation of displaced individuals; and (2) the General Services Administration (GSA) related to the consequences of the hurricanes for the Federal Buildings Fund.

Title III: Emergency Agricultural Disaster Assistance Act of 2006 - Emergency Agricultural Disaster Assistance Act of 2006 - (Sec. 3002) Defines specified terms.

Defines "hurricane-affected county" as a county covered by a natural disaster designation related to Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, or Wilma, or a related condition, and each county contiguous to such county.

Subtitle A: Agricultural Production Losses - (Sec. 3011) Directs the Secretary of Agriculture to provide emergency financial assistance to eligible agricultural producers (other than sugarcane and sugar beet producers) who have incurred qualifying: (1) 2005 crop losses due to weather or related conditions (including crop disease, insects, and delayed harvest); and (2) 2006 crop losses due to flooding in California and Hawaii that occurred prior to the date of enactment of this Act and for which a petition for a disaster designation has been filed with the Secretary.

(Sec. 3012) Directs the Secretary to provide: (1) payments through the 2002 livestock compensation program for 2005 and 2006 livestock disaster losses that occurred prior to enactment of this Act (including wildfire disaster losses in Texas and other states); (2) livestock indemnity payments for 2005 and 2006 livestock disaster losses that occurred prior to enactment of this Act (including wildfire disaster losses in Texas and other states), including losses due to hurricanes, floods, wildfires, and anthrax; and (3) indemnity payments to poultry producers in hurricane-affected counties, and for 2006 ewe lamb replacement and retention.

(Sec. 3013) Directs the Secretary to provide compensation for certain owners of flooded crop and grazing land in North Dakota.

(Sec. 3014) Directs the Secretary to provide: (1) sugarcane and sugar beet disaster assistance for qualifying first processors in Louisiana counties designated as disaster areas due to Hurricanes Katrina or Rita, or related conditions; (2) assistance to qualifying sugar beet producers who suffered 2005 production losses; (3) sugarcane and sugar beet assistance for qualifying producers and first processors in Florida for 2005 losses in hurricane-affected counties due to hurricanes, floods, rain, or storms; (4) assistance to sugarcane growers in Texas by making a payment to the Rio Grande Valley Sugar Growers for additional Baton Rouge demurrage costs and raw sugar transportation and storage costs resulting from 2005 hurricanes, flooding, and related conditions; and (5) assistance to sugarcane growers in Hawaii for an agricultural transportation cooperative.

(Sec. 3015) Directs the Secretary to provide assistance to specialty and nursery crop producers in hurricane-affected counties.

(Sec. 3016) Directs the Secretary to provide assistance to dairy producers for production and spoilage losses in hurricane-affected counties.

(Sec. 3017) Directs the Secretary to provide assistance to producers and first handlers of cottonseed.

(Sec. 3018) Reduces assistance under this subtitle by amounts for the same or similar loss under: (1) the Department of Defense, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico, and Pandemic Influenza Act, 2006; or (2) an agricultural disaster assistance provision contained in the Secretary's announcement of January 26, 2006.

Subtitle B: Supplemental Nutrition and Agricultural Economic Disaster Assistance - (Sec. 3021) Directs the Secretary to make grants to eligible states for: (1) agricultural promotion, with set-asides for Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia; and (2) value of production (based upon a state's share of the total value of U.S. specialty crop, livestock, and dairy production).

(Sec. 3022) Directs the Secretary to make supplemental economic loss payments under a specified rate to producers who received crop year 2005 commodity assistance.

(Sec. 3023) Reduces assistance under this subtitle by amounts for the same or similar loss under: (1) the Department of Defense, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico, and Pandemic Influenza Act, 2006; or (2) an agricultural disaster assistance provision contained in the Secretary's announcement of January 26, 2006.

Subtitle C: Forestry - (Sec. 3031) Directs the Secretary to provide assistance to: (1) tree producers (including Christmas, potted, ornamental, and nursery trees, bushes and shrubs, and vines) in hurricane-affected counties; and (2) fruit and tree nut producers in hurricane-affected counties for site preparation, replacement, rehabilitation, and pruning.

Subtitle D: Conservation - (Sec. 3041) Authorizes the Secretary to: (1) provide financial and technical assistance to remove debris and animal carcasses that could adversely affect health and safety on non-federal land in hurricane-affected counties; and (2) use direct check-writing practices and electronic transfers to provide financial and technical assistance under the emergency watershed protection program in hurricane-affected counties.

(Sec. 3042) Directs the Secretary to make additional emergency watershed protection funds available for emergency measures identified by the Natural Resources Conservation Service.

(Sec. 3043) Directs the Secretary to make additional emergency conservation funds available for emergency measures identified by the Farm Service Agency.

Subtitle E: Farm Service Agency - (Sec. 3051) Directs the Secretary to hire additional state and county Farm Service Agency personnel to assist in agricultural disaster and economic assistance programs.

Subtitle F: Miscellaneous - (Sec. 3061) Authorizes the Secretary to provide immunizations to Department of Agriculture employees involved in direct recovery work in hurricane-affected counties.

(Sec. 3062) Authorizes the Secretary to provide emergency conservation assistance in hurricane-affected counties without regard to wetlands-related provisions.

(Sec. 3063) Directs the Secretary to use Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC) funds, facilities, and authorities to carry out this title, which shall remain available until expended.

Subtitle G: Emergency Designation - (Sec. 3071) Designates amounts provided under this title as an emergency requirement.

Title IV: Drought Emergency Assistance - (Sec. 4001) Appropriates, in addition to any other funds under this Act, emergency drought assistance funds for: (1) the Army Corps of Engineers; and (2) the Bureau of Reclamation (Department of the Interior).

(Sec. 4003) Designates amounts provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement.

Title V: Port Security Enhancements - Appropriates funds for: (1) customs and border protection for salaries and expenses; (2) the U.S. Coast Guard's operating expenses; (3) the Office for Domestic Preparedness for state and local programs; and (4) the Domestic Nuclear Detection Office for research, development, acquisition, and operations.

Title VI: Pandemic Flu - Appropriates funds to the Department of Health and Human Services for the Public Health and Social Services Emergency Fund to: (1) prepare for and respond to an influenza pandemic; and (2) compensate individuals harmed by such vaccines.

Designates amounts provided for such purposes as an emergency requirement.

Title VII: Border Security - Emergency Supplemental Appropriations for Border Security - Appropriates additional funds to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for: (1) the Office of the Secretary and Executive Management solely for a contract with an independent non-federal entity to conduct a needs assessment for comprehensive border security; (2) the Office of the Chief Information Officer to replace and upgrade law enforcement communications; (3) the U.S. Visitor and Immigration Status Indicator Technology to accelerate biometric database integration and conversion to 10-print enrollment; (4) Customs and Border Protection for salaries and expenses; (5) "Air and Marine Interdiction, Operations, Maintenance, and Procurement" to replace air assets and upgrade air operations facilities; (6) construction; (7) Immigration and Customs Enforcement for salaries and expenses; (8) the U.S. Coast Guard for acquisition, construction, renovation, and improvement of vessels, aircraft, and equipment; and (9) the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center for acquisition, construction, improvements, and related expenses for construction of a certain language training facility and for information technology infrastructure improvements.

Designates amounts provided for such purposes as an emergency requirement.

(Sec. 7001) Reduces the aggregate amount provided under this Act to the DOD for the military and further hurricane disaster relief and recovery.

Title VIII: Other Matters - Appropriates additional funds to the Architect of the Capitol (AOC) for the U.S. Capitol power plant.

Designates amounts provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement.

(Sec. 8001) Prohibits funds appropriated or otherwise made available in this Act for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) for "Operations, Research, and Facilities" from being made available for the National Marine Fisheries Service to implement seafood promotion strategies. Reduces such NOAA funds by $15 million.

Title IX: General Provisions and Technical Corrections - (Sec. 9002) Makes certain funds, otherwise available for Paul Coverdell Forensic Sciences Improvement Grants under the Department of Justice Appropriations Act, 2006, available to the Attorney General for a specified study of forensic science.

(Sec. 9003) Deems the conference report accompanying the Science, State, Justice, Commerce, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006 to require certain amounts made available for the Mitchell Institute in Portland, Maine, to be for the science and engineering education endowment.

(Sec. 9004) Amends the same Act to shift funds earmarked for the Clark County Department of Aviation, Las Vegas, Nevada, for the international air trade show to the University of Nevada Las Vegas for the same purpose.

(Sec. 9005) Deems funds appropriated or made available by the transfer of funds in or pursuant to this Act for intelligence activities to be specifically authorized by Congress for purposes of the National Security Act of 1947.

(Sec. 9007) Requires certain funds provided in the Department of Defense, Emergency Supplemental Appropriations to Address Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico, and Pandemic Influenza Act, 2006 for the Louisiana hurricane protection study to be provided at full federal expense.

(Sec. 9008) Amends the same Act to direct the Corps of Engineers to accelerate completion of any study or any unconstructed portion of the Mississippi River and Tributaries project for the flood and storm damage reduction projects in the south Louisiana area.

Designates amounts provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement.

(Sec. 9009) Earmarks certain funds appropriated in the same Act for the repair, construction, or provision of measures or structures necessary to protect, restore, or increase wetlands (in the Mississippi River-Gulf of Mexico outlet) to prevent saltwater intrusion or storm surge.

Designates amounts provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement.

(Sec. 9010) Amends the Water Resources Development Act of 1996 to require the Secretary of the Army to extend from six to seven years the national shoreline erosion control development and demonstration program.

Increases the authorization of appropriations for such program from $21 million to $25 million.

(Sec. 9011) Amends the Reclamation States Emergency Drought Relief Act of 1991 to extend the drought program through FY2005-FY2010.

Continues the authorization of appropriations for such Act for FY2006-FY2010.

(Sec. 9012) Prohibits the expenditure of any funds to prevent or limit any reprogramming of funds for a project to be carried out by the Corps of Engineers using energy and water development appropriations, based on whether the project was included in the President's budget or is otherwise proposed by the President or considered part of it by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), if the project received funds in an Act making such appropriations.

(Sec. 9013) Prohibits the use of funds during FY2006 or before April 1, 2007, for any payment on bonds issued by the Administrator of the Bonneville Power Administration (Administrator) or for an appropriated Federal Columbia River Power System investment, if the payment is both: (1) greater, during any fiscal year, than the payments calculated in the Administrator's rate hearing using the repayment method used to establish such rates as in effect on February 6, 2006; and (2) based or conditioned on the actual or expected net secondary power sales receipts of the Administrator.

(Sec. 9014) Rescinds $3.96 million of funds appropriated to the DHS for "Screening Coordination and Operations."

Appropriates the same additional amount for the DHS Office of the Secretary and Executive Management.

(Sec. 9015) Appropriates additional funds to the Department of the Interior for "U.S. Geological Survey, Surveys, Investigations, and Research," to remain available until expended, for assistance with assessments of critical reservoirs and dams, including the monitoring of dam structure.

Designates amounts provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement.

(Sec. 9016) Amends the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 to extend from June 30, 2006, through FY2007 payment of the current reclamation fee by operators of coal mining operations for deposit in the fund under the Act (after which time, as under current law, the fee is to be established at a new rate to continue to provide for such deposit).

(Sec. 9017) Prohibits the expenditure of funds made available under this Act or under the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006, for any activity that: (1) is related to carrying out Order 09-2006 of the Secretary of Labor; or (2) transfers the Office of Job Corps but does not establish it as a single office within the Office of the Secretary that retains all staff, functions and authorities related to carrying out the Job Corps requirements of the Workforce Investment Act of 1998.

(Sec. 9018) Appropriates additional funds through FY2007 under "Department of Labor, Mine Safety and Health Administration, Salaries and Expenses" for the inspection of coal mines.

Designates amounts provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement.

(Sec. 9019) Appropriates additional funds through FY2007 for "Department of Health and Human Services, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Disease Control, Research and Training" to carry out the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 for research to develop mine safety technology including grants and contracts.

Designates amounts provided for such purpose as an emergency requirement.

(Sec. 9020) Amends the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2006, under "Railroad Retirement Board, Dual Benefits Payments Account," to revise the formula for payment of additional funds to the Dual Benefits Payments Account.
